qas.question: What kind of occupation do Hindu scriptures describe hunting as being?
What is one of the names of the god Shiva?
What is the translation of Mrigavyadha?
What does Shiva destroy in human beings?
What scriptures describe hunting as and acceptable occupation?
Godly figures have engaged in what activity?
Mrigavyadha destroys animal instinct in who?
What happened after Krishna was accidentally wounded by an arrow of a hunter?

plausible_answers.text: by an arrow of a hunter

qas.question: How was Shiva accidentally wounded to later die?
What does Ramayana destroy in animals?
How is Krishna said to be able to hunt?
Who did Krishna mistake for game and accidentally kill?

context: <a5_0>Hindu<a5_0/> scriptures describe hunting as an <a0_0>acceptable<a0_0/> occupation, as well as a sport of the kingly. Even figures considered godly are described to have engaged in <a6_0>hunting<a6_0/>. One of the names of the god Shiva is <a1_0>Mrigavyadha<a1_0/>, which translates as <a2_0>"the <a7_0>deer hunter<a7_0/>"<a2_0/> (mriga means deer; vyadha means hunter). The word Mriga, in many Indian languages including Malayalam, not only stands for deer, but for all animals and animal instincts (Mriga Thrishna). Shiva, as Mrigavyadha, is the one who destroys the <a3_0><b11_0>animal instincts<b11_0/><a3_0/> in <a8_0>human beings<a8_0/>. In the epic Ramayana, Dasharatha, the father of Rama, is said to have the ability to <a4_0>hunt <b12_0>in the dark<b12_0/><a4_0/>. During one of his hunting expeditions, he accidentally killed <b13_0>Shravana<b13_0/>, mistaking him for game. During Rama's exile in <b14_0>the forest<b14_0/>, Ravana kidnapped his wife, Sita, from their hut, while Rama was asked by Sita to capture a golden deer, and his brother Lakshman went after him. According to the Mahabharat, Pandu, the father of the Pandavas, accidentally killed the sage Kindama and his wife with an arrow, mistaking them for a deer. Krishna is said to have <a9_0>died<a9_0/> after being accidentally wounded <b10_0>by an arrow of a hunter<b10_0/>.
